It’s really easy for adults to do this kind of thing unconsciously.  It’s easy to get caught up in the notion that “They’re in time out, and that’s the end of it!” but kids can be pretty imaginative, and they can use their own creativity to make their way out of time outs.  A compassionate time out ends when the child shows a sign of understanding what they’ve done wrong, and are ready to begin again.  That way the child knows they’re learning, and that the parent is seeing them as an intelligent person, even if they sometimes mess up.  You can still use the other techniques you were using to be tough when necessary, but using a compassionate approach will let you use them without actually using them!

Now, the phrase "Thank you very much" is more of an assurance that the person being addressed is being thanked extremely. This car would also have some sensors, but it wouldn’t really need them, because it would always have access to so much more information than you do.  When you are driving, you would choose where you want to go, and your car would use all of its data to come up with the best route and way to get there. There are two endogenous receptors for dopamine, which work by binding to the neurotransmitter and transporting it elsewhere in the body, without which dopamine is only bound to the cell membrane or transported to the synaptic space of other neurons, in which they bind and transport it away from the transmitter. In the boosting dopamine levels sense, the environment could be changed so that a greater number of these neurotransmitters are released, but this won’t actually change the amount of the neurotransmitter that is bound to the receptors."

5 potatoes (red skinned if possible, they have a sweet taste), cubed

2-3 tomatoes, finely chopped (6-8 tbsp)

1 tsp ginger, grated

1 tsp salt

2-3 cloves of garlic, crushed

1⁄2 tsp red chili powder

2-3 tbsp cumin powder

1 tbsp coriander powder

1 tbsp garam masala

2 tbsp lemon juice

1⁄2 cup (2 oz) coriander, chopped (optional)

Cooking oil

----

Heat cooking oil in a deep pan or kadhai, add the onion, and fry it until it turns light golden.

Remove the onions and drain on a paper towel. Leave the oil in the pan.

Add the tomatoes, ginger, garlic, and salt, stir and cook for about 3 minutes.

Add the chili powder, cumin, coriander, and garam masala. Stir well, and cook for 2 minutes.

Add the potatoes, and cook for 2 minutes.

Turn the heat down, and mix well. Add 2-3 tbsp water, and cook for 8-10 minutes. Keep stirring and checking.

Add the lemon juice. Remove from heat. Mix in the coriander and let it cool a little.

Cut potatoes and tomato and shape into balls.

Heat some cooking oil in a deep pan or kadhai. When the oil is hot, add the potatoes. Fry till they turn light golden brown.

In a paper towel, drain the fried potatoes. Leave the oil in the pan.

In the same oil, add the onion, tomatoes, and fried potatoes.

Stir well, and add 2-3 tbsp water. Cook for 3-4 minutes.

----

This rewritten code uses a list comprehension and the string format function to print the word counts by frequency. The words are listed according to the number of their occurrences.
@lru_cache(maxsize=None)
def word_count(text):
    """
    Prints the number of times each word appears in a text.  Note: this is a very
    basic word counter and does not account for punctuation (like "or"), or
    numbers or case (e.g. "Apple" and "apple").  It's also not especially well
    suited to more complex texts.  Here's a much more sophisticated version:
    http://stackoverflow.com/questions/15157195/word-frequencies-in-a-text
    """
    words = [word for word in text.lower().split() if word]
    words.sort(key=lambda x: len(x), reverse=True)
    return words
